recommendation: Apply Chlorantraniliprole-based granules to the soil before planting. Use beneficial nematodes to control larvae biologically. Rotate crops to reduce infestations.
Use Imidacloprid soil drench or Bifenthrin-based insecticides. Apply biological controls like parasitic nematodes or fungal pathogens such as Beauveria bassiana.
Use seed treatments containing Thiamethoxam or Clothianidin. Incorporate crop rotation with non-host crops like legumes. Maintain well-drained soil to reduce wireworm survival.
Apply Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) formulations or use transgenic Bt corn hybrids. Introduce Trichogramma wasps to control eggs biologically. Avoid late planting to minimize infestation.
Use insecticidal soaps or Neem oil for organic control. Apply systemic insecticides like Acetamiprid or Flonicamid for heavy infestations. Encourage natural predators such as ladybugs and lacewings.
Use Spinosad or Emamectin benzoate-based treatments. Release beneficial insects such as parasitic wasps (Cotesia spp.). Employ pheromone traps for monitoring adult moths.
Apply Pyrethroid-based sprays like Cypermethrin or Deltamethrin during early larval stages. Use crop rotation and avoid planting near infested areas.
Use Carbaryl or Permethrin-based insecticides for severe infestations. Introduce natural enemies like birds and predatory insects. Maintain proper weed control to eliminate alternative hosts.
Apply Spinosad or Lambda-cyhalothrin-based insecticides. Avoid harvesting during peak beetle activity to prevent contamination. Use row covers to reduce beetle invasion.
Hand-pick beetles in small infestations. Use Pyrethroid-based insecticides like Bifenthrin for larger outbreaks. Avoid mowing infested fields to reduce risk of beetle swarms.

Apply selective insecticides such as Flupyradifurone or Pyrethroids if population exceeds economic threshold. Use pheromone-based monitoring techniques. Encourage natural predators such as predatory mirid bugs.
Apply Chlorantraniliprole or Lufenuron for caterpillar control. Use pheromone traps to monitor adult moths. Maintain field hygiene by removing fallen leaves and debris.
Use systemic insecticides such as Imidacloprid or Thiamethoxam. Introduce biological controls like predatory bugs (Orius spp.). Apply reflective mulches to deter egg-laying by adults.
